Topic.Title: Oppenheimer: "AMZN Driven By Momentum Traders, Not Fundamental"

Message.Msg: Amazon raised prices on shipping. Maybe someone actually noticed gross shipping cost as a percent of net sales has increased over the years and even net shipping cost as a percent of net sales had plateaued because it is about the last mile, not the intermediate mile.... The buildout has been about trying to reduce the magnitude of the negative impact from higher fuel/transport costs. Unless and until Amazon establishes its own fleet to compete directly with FedEx and UPS (which built their massive fleets over decades through actual earnings), the benefit will diminish rapidly. Frankly, UPS and FedEx should end MFN pricing for Amazon. Let it try to use USPS for everything... It would be game over because it is their network that actually has the scale and delivery density for the last mile.

Message.Title: Amazon Web Services Fails The Price/Performance Test. But Does It Matter?
Message.Msg: ...Cloud Spectator took the leading cloud vendors as defined by Gartner’s Magic Quadrant and put them through a series of tests measuring overall performance, application latency, application throughput and consistency over time, in addition to considering both raw performance and cost/hour of the service to compare results. To ensure the analysis compared apples with apples, as far as possible, the tests match the services tested (CPU, memory, disk space), based on comparable offerings from the cloud providers. Essentially Cloud Spectator tried to create a common framework to measure vendors against one-another. And the results are pretty interesting – such well known cloud vendors as Softlayer, Terremark, Rackspace and AWS feature near the bottom of the list. While big names, but less respected vendors such as Virtustream, HP and Microsoft MSFT -1.52% come out on top....

Topic.Title: BEZOS BLOOD BATH EARNING ESTIMATES:Surprise % -650.00%

Message.Msg: Internet retailer Amazon (AMZN) will release its Q3 2013 earnings on October 24. Evidence suggests that while the company’s growth will exceed that of the overall e-commerce market, it is likely to come down as compared to the third quarter of 2012. The primary reason behind this is Amazon’s growing size and the recent slowdown in the U.S. e-commerce market. In Q2 2013, Amazon’s revenues jumped 22% globally, with the electronics and general merchandise segment leading the way. Despite this, the company reported a net operating loss and missed consensus estimates, which reflects the pressure on its margins resulting from the rapid expansion. This trend is likely to continue in the third quarter as Amazon remains committed to driving its sales volumes. This strategy could be risky if market dynamics were to change and brick and mortar retailers launch a full-fledged assault on Amazon’s turf. The established retailers such as Wal-Mart (WMT) already have a strong supply chain and are certainly capable of matching Amazon in prices. Our price estimate for Amazon stands at $280, implying a discount of about 15% to the market price. Amazon expects net sales of between $15.45 billion and $17.15 billion in the third quarter, implying a growth of somewhere between 12% and 24% over Q3 2012. [1] The operating loss is likely to increase, but the majority of it will result from higher stock based compensation.

Message.Title: AMZN's return free risk: the epitome of broken, corrupt markets...
Message.Msg: Well folks, it is almost game time. Not one analyst would put 25% of his or her money into AMZN at these levels if he or she had to hold until either 1) his/her price target was hit or 2) 90 days after publicly changing it. Not one. So, we'll see just how morally bankrupt and intellectually dishonest the analyst community and WS at large have become. As I've said about a thousand times on this board, markets cannot function without trust and those playing these games are eroding trust by the day. It is easy to destroy and hard to rebuild. Trust isthe real fundamental of the marketplace. And, when it's been destroyed, Wall Street is dead. Done. Kaput. We may already have passed the point of no return, but I keep hoping that institutions will finally do the right thing and let the market come back into balance... While AMZN is return free risk, reverse AAPLTrage (selling AMZN and buying AAPL) has become risk free return. Converting .2% unencumbered (real) FCF yield for about 10% unencumbered (real) FCF yield is a pretty safe play... The pain trade rebalancing play has petered out. The indexes have been stuffed to the gills with garbage (which was what the entire pain trade was about) so there's no more room for float jam scams. From now on, rebalancing creates a negative feedback loop for float jam scams. Someday, folks will look back and realize how retail once again (via ETF stuffing) has scam #$%$ dumped on it... My prediction is that AMZN hits 261ish before Jan 1st.

God speed to him! Long live JB!

Topic.Title: Bezos haz a good plan for making arsloadz of money

Message.Msg: If the market was not totally broken and totally corrupt, it never would have reached $205. A reasonable valuation is sub $100... The problem with all asset bubbles fueled by massive malinvestment is in the long run, assets must be supported by cash flows. Even with the Fed;s $85B in monopoly money for TBTF/PD/BB, we have aging boomers that need to cash out to support living standards. The demographics that, coupled with the launch of the IRA, helped fuel the perma bubble of historically high CAPE multiples, is about to reverse and hard... There is only 1 way out of this situation. Only one. And it isn't going to be good for Scamazon.
